channel.title: Recording on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in Recording on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: You’ve written a song. Or you were handed one by somebody else. It sounds great when you play it live, or the demo is very promising.

item.title: The Disconnect
item.description: Why is recording music so hard? Why can’t we just do a good performance (live), capture it with a microphone, and we’re done?

item.title: Equipment I: Essentials
item.description: This chapter explains what you surely need to start recording audio. The next chapter will only go over things that are certainly useful but not essential.

item.title: Equipment II: Useful
item.description: Over the years, I’ve collected many extra tools—both tiny and huge—to help with the recording process. I’ll explain them in this chapter.

item.title: Space I: Acoustics
item.description: I’ve already given you an important intuition for acoustic treatment. This chapter will explain the practical side of it.

item.title: Space II: Environment
item.description: Okay, let’s recap. You have your equipment: your entire audio chain. Your room was treated to sound as good as it can be (to a microphone), and you understand why that matters.

item.title: Arrangement
item.description: Your setup is ready. Your room is ready. Your song is ready … right? Not quite. When I started recording, I thought I entered my booth well-prepared.

item.title: Monitoring
item.description: Throughout this guide, I’ve mentioned the word monitoring multiple times. Now we can finally dive into what it is exactly and why it matters so much.

item.title: Singing with Headphones
item.description: Vocals present the most problems when it comes to recording audio. And these problems mostly stem from bad monitoring.

item.title: Phase Issues
item.description: This is a rather advanced topic. But I wanted to discuss it now, because it explains why the next chapters are the way they are.

item.title: Microphones
item.description: Finally, we’re ready for chapters about the nitty-gritty practical details on recording. You understand why things go wrong and the many challenges when it comes to recording.

item.title: Microphone Placement
item.description: Yes, this chapter will tell you where to place your microphone. But there are no “rules”, not really. You should try your microphones in many locations and pick the one that sounds best.

item.title: Gain Staging
item.description: There’s an annoying side-effect from converting analog sound ( = physical audio in the real world) to digital sound ( = on your computer).

item.title: Sessions
item.description: Finally, we can talk about the actual act of recording. In detail, with practical tips and tricks. This chapter is about each session.

item.title: Takes
item.description: You started your session well. Your microphones are all in place and you’re warmed up. Now it’s time to do individual recordings—individual takes.

item.title: Piano
item.description: I’d recommend learning the piano to anyone. It’s probably the easiest instrument to understand (in a short amount of time), but also the most versatile.

item.title: Guitar
item.description: The second instrument I’d recommend to anyone, is guitar. It’s a completely different array of sounds and rhythms than piano.

item.title: Drums
item.description: Drums are the third instrument I suggest you learn (well). They are the silent hero of most songs. Without them, the whole song falls apart or sounds lifeless.

item.title: Conclusion
